I'm sure a rare example of someone with seemingly boundless energy is my grandfather. It seems his motto is, "Life's too short to be idle."

Now in his late 70s and retired, he could sleep late, spend more time in bed, read books, or watch TV. But instead, he's always on the go, despite his age. He wakes up with the sun and starts his day with morning exercises outdoors, regardless of the weather or season. Then he gets to work on chores like washing and cleaning. Since my grandmother passed away 20 years ago, he's done all the housework himself. He also works in the yard, the orchard, and his vegetable garden. Yet, he never seems to feel tired. At least, he never says he's tired. In fact, the more he does, the more energized he seems to get. It's incredible. I'm just 30, and I'm nowhere near as active as him. At the end of the day, I can't wait to get home and collapse on the couch. My grandfather, on the other hand, is always up for an evening stroll. I rely on extra-large coffees to get through the day, but he never relies on caffeine. He believes the most powerful source of energy comes from within.

When people ask him how he stays so energized, he always says there are three keys to living a vibrant life. First, he says his energy levels are directly tied to how refreshed he feels each morning. He never sacrifices sleep, especially for TV, and he eats well. Second, he surrounds himself with the right people - those who are passionate about life, knowledge, and work - and avoids people who constantly complain. Finally, he believes in doing something meaningful with his time. He spreads enthusiasm to everyone around him, and his energy is infectious. I can't help admiring him and wish there were more people like him.

My grandfather was a doctor. He had been working at a regional hospital for more than 50 years until he retired. He started his career as a doctor's assistant, and later became a doctor. He examined, diagnosed and treated patients. He literally worked day and night. I think it was hard. Very hard. But I'm sure that he did exactly what he was born to do, and he wouldn't have changed his job for all the world. For him, it wasn't just a job, it was his calling.

My grandfather's work occupied all his time. He never had a second job. It was just impossible as he had no time for that. If he had had a second job, he would have died of fatigue. Sometimes I doubted my grandfather was a human being. He didn't have hobbies. He didn't spend time with friends. He even missed most family gatherings. You know, it's not fun at all. He was always tired, and his eyes were always red because of endless sleepless nights. When he wasn't on duty, he was reading different books and reviewing medical records of his patients.

In my opinion, it is a very rewarding job. But I wouldn't like to do anything like that because it's really stressful, especially when you understand that you cannot help some patient. Plus, shift work is not my thing. I can't imagine myself working night shifts. What's more, I don't want to sacrifice everything for work.

Since childhood I've been interested in Astronomy. Astrophysics, to be precise. This is the branch of Astronomy that studies the physics of stellar phenomena and other objects in space. Though I have to admit that I'm not a science-obsessed person. I mean, if I come across an interesting article, I read it with pleasure. If I don’t, I don’t deliberately search for this information, nor do I do it regularly. From time to time I watch documentaries, read articles on the Internet, get some new information from friends. But as I've said before, I don't do it very often.

I don’t really remember what got me into space and all that stuff. It feels like I’ve been interested in it for as long as I can remember.. For example, by the time I was five, I already recall being interested in Astronomy.. I think I got started on the science track when I started reading a lot of science fiction books and encyclopedias as a child. Also, my parents read me books on planets and my father told me many interesting facts about our solar system. My interest to this topic was fueled several years ago after watching Interstellar, a wonderful science fiction movie which made me think about black holes, wormholes, space time, dark matter, time dilation for several weeks. I was more than impressed.

The main reason why I like Astrophysics is that everything mysterious captivates me. I really want to understand how everything that exists works, to have a better understanding of the universe we live in and understand how the cosmos influences different processes on our planet.

In my experience, things go wrong when I least expect it. Last winter, I had an overnight bus journey from Big City to Cool City.

When I found out I needed to make this trip, train tickets were already sold out, and buying a plane ticket was out of the question. It was way too expensive. So, taking the bus was my only option at the time.

I hate travelling long distances by bus, especially at night, mostly because I can't sleep sitting up. This was exactly the case. Since I couldn't sleep, I stared out of the window. It was almost dawn, so I could barely see anything, but it was still better than staring at the back of the seat in front of me.

Suddenly I heard a dull thud, and a few minutes later, the bus stopped. The driver got off to check, but he didn’t come back for half an hour.

At first, everything seemed ok. All the passengers were sleeping and had no idea something was wrong. If I had been able to sleep, I probably wouldn’t have noticed anything either. But unfortunately, I wasn’t as lucky as the others.

Several hours later everyone woke up and realized that we were stuck in the middle of nowhere. The worst part? There was no toilet - not even trees or bushes in sight. Just an endless field. For people like me, who are used to modern conveniences, it was a nightmare.

As time went on, people grew angrier by the hour. Some passengers even lost their temper and started yelling at the driver, even though it wasn’t his fault. He was doing everything he could to fix the problem, but it wasn’t easy.

We ended up spending five or six hours on the side of the highway before we could finally continue the journey.. But I wasn't really happy because I missed a very important meeting.

Last Sunday, I went to the village to visit my grandparents. During the pandemic, I didn’t visit them at all because I was afraid to infect them. I missed them very much. My grandpa even said he was more afraid to die of loneliness than of coronavirus. So since the pandemic, I’ve been visiting them more often to make up for the time we lost even though it takes me 5 hours to get there.

My grandparents live in a quiet and beautiful place by the river. They have a cozy house with a big garden. There are lots of flowers, and sometimes orchids bloom too. You know, being there is like travelling back in time. Everything reminds me of my carefree childhood: my toys, old CDs, my bicycle. It feels like you step into another world. All the walls are still covered with old wallpaper. My grandmother doesn’t allow us to remove it, and she refuses to get their house refurbished because she wants to keep all their memories alive. She says they both love their 50-year-old chairs and armchairs, their old wooden table in the kitchen, paintings, clay pots, old pictures, and lots of things they bought when they were young.

You know, I think she’s right. There’s something special about this old house. It’s a magical place, and I really love spending time there. When I visit, I enjoy going fishing and exploring the countryside during the day. In the evenings, I watch the sunset from the backyard. I drink hot tea and eat cinnamon buns. My grandmother always bakes them when I come because she knows how much I love them. If I didn't have so much on my plate and if the trip didn't take so long, I would visit them more often.

About six months ago, I read this book called The Miracle Morning. It really inspired me to try waking up at 5 a.m.

At first, it was insanely hard because I was the type of person who would stay in bed as long as possible, hitting snooze like five times. But little by little, it got easier. Finally, I got used to waking up early. And now I wake up at 5 a.m. without any struggle.

Honestly, it’s been a game-changer for me. Before, I used to wake up already feeling tired, like I’d been carrying heavy loads all night. I’d feel drained all day long. I used to drink three cups of coffee just to function. And even that didn’t always help. I have no idea how it works, but now I feel full of energy.

This change has made me so much more productive, both at work and at home. Plus, I finally have time for myself. In the mornings, while everyone else is still asleep, I read, do yoga, meditate, and plan my day. Sometimes, I watch interesting YouTube videos or listen to podcasts. So I can see how much my life has improved because of this simple habit.

I usually ask for an exchange if there’s something wrong with my purchase. I only return things when the product can’t be fixed or exchanged, or if it didn’t meet my expectations. That’s exactly what happened with a pair of sneakers I bought a few weeks ago. I bought them because I saw a big discount online and thought, ‘Wow, such a great deal!’ I placed the order right away, without second-guessing. When I tried them on at home, they seemed perfect. They looked amazing and felt fine. I couldn’t wait to wear them out. So I decided to take them for a walk the very next day.

When I started walking, I felt something was off, but at that point, I couldn't figure out what exactly was wrong. The next day, I gave them another shot. I was hoping they’d get better with time. But they didn’t. This time, it hurt everywhere, and my left foot was literally one big blister. The sneakers were beautiful and high-quality, but I knew I’d never wear them again. So I had no choice but to return them.

Thank God, the store had a simple return policy. I just filled out a form online, packed the sneakers back into the box, and dropped them off at the nearest courier service. Within a week, I got my refund.

This mishap happened to me a long time ago, but I still remember it like it was yesterday. My boss invited me to lunch to discuss my long-term career plans. I had even heard through the grapevine that he was going to offer me a new position and a bigger project.

One day, when I was supposed to be at the café, I was in the office working as if everything was normal. It wasn’t until I saw my boss’s name on my phone screen that I remembered our meeting.

You know, I was absolutely shocked. I had a panic attack, and I just wanted the ground to open up and swallow me. I couldn’t believe I had completely forgotten about it. It just slipped my mind.

I realized how awful the situation was. My boss had rearranged his busy schedule to meet me, and I hadn’t even shown up. I felt deeply ashamed of what had happened, and I didn’t have a single excuse. I felt so guilty knowing he had wasted his valuable time waiting for me instead of focusing on something important. I was terrified that he might think I didn’t value the opportunity or respect his time.

On top of that, I was in shock because nothing like this had ever happened to me before, and I didn’t know how to handle it. Of course, I apologized a hundred times, but it didn’t make me feel any better. I knew he had wasted his precious time because of me, and I couldn’t forgive myself for it.

So, at my work, there's this one rule that everyone knows about, and it's all about being on time. It's a pretty simple rule, really. But it's super important for keeping things running smoothly. I mean we work in a busy office where we have to coordinate a lot of tasks and projects. If someone is late, it can mess up the whole schedule. Meetings get delayed, deadlines get pushed back, and it can be a real headache for everyone. So if it weren't for this rule, we would have a really hard time getting work done. Literally.

So, I totally get why this rule is in place, and I actually think it's a good one. It helps us stay organized and make sure we're all on the same page. Plus, it shows respect for our colleagues and the company because we're valuing everyone's time.

But here's the thing: not everyone followed this rule. There were a few coworkers who were constantly late, and it was frustrating. It was not fair to the rest of us who made an effort to be on time, and it often created tension in the office.

Now, if someone does break this rule and is late without a good reason, there are consequences. Usually, our boss will have a chat with them and remind them of the importance of being punctual. If it keeps happening, they might get a formal warning. And if it continues after that, well, they could even lose their job.

So, while the rule about being on time might seem strict, I think it's necessary to keep things running smoothly and maintain a respectful work environment. And personally, I'm all for it because it makes my workday a lot less stressful.

In my school, there's this really long list of rules we have to follow. Most of them are there to make sure the school is safe and orderly and that we students behave ourselves. But some of these rules are just way too strict. Like, we have to wear a uniform. Girls wear a shirt, a knee-length woolen skirt, socks or tights, and shoes. Boys wear a shirt and trousers. And we can only buy our uniforms from one specific place to make sure we all look exactly the same. No other options are allowed. Then there's the whole thing about how we look. Piercings are not allowed. No jewelry, no makeup, and we can't even have our hair dyed. If you have long hair, it has to be tied back all the time.

Now, don't get me wrong, I get that wearing a uniform is practical and it helps keep distractions in check. When everyone dresses the same way, it's easier to focus on schoolwork instead of what people are wearing. And no one gets teased for not following fashion trends, which is nice.

But honestly, at my school, these rules are just over the top. I mean, I get it if we came to school in ripped jeans, that's not cool. But why the heck should plain blue jeans with no fancy stuff be a problem. Shirts have to be tucked in, which is fine. It makes us look neat. But if your socks aren't pulled up or your shoes' heel straps aren't perfect, you can be sent home or given a talking to. And if you dare to wear even tiny earrings, they make you take them out. You can't even go back to class until your parents meet with the principal or teacher. That's insane. And for the boys, if they wear the wrong kind of shoes or trousers, they can get detention or even suspended for one to ten days. Thank God, we don't have physical punishment.

Honestly, without the uniform policy, I think we'd be showing up in all sort of outfits like sweaters, short skirts, hoodies, you name it. Most of us would probably have tattoos and piercings galore. It'd be a total mess. But the extreme rules we have in our school aren't much better.

A few years ago, I made a decision that completely changed my life. I had been working at the same company for nearly 5 years. It was a stable job with a steady income, but deep down I knew I wasn't happy. I felt like I was stuck in a rut and there were no opportunities to grow professionally or be promoted. I had always dreamed of starting my own business, but the idea of leaving my stable job and taking such a big risk was terrifying. However, as time went on, I became more and more unhappy with my current situation. I began to realize that if I didn't make a change soon, I might regret it for the rest of my life.

I started doing research, talking to other entrepreneurs, and developing a business plan. I also spoke to my friends and family about my decision and sought their support.

It wasn't an easy decision to leave my stable job, but I knew it was the right one. I was nervous about the financial risk and the potential for failure, but I also felt excited about the prospect of pursuing my dream and creating something that was truly my own.

It's been a few years since I started my business, and it hasn't always been easy. There have been many ups and downs, but I have never regretted my decision to take the leap. I feel fulfilled and challenged in a way that I never did in my previous job, and I know that I made the right choice for myself and my future.

When Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, I found myself faced with a difficult decision. I lived near the border, so I couldn't risk staying to see what would happen. I knew I had to make a quick decision and evacuate the country as soon as possible, for the safety of myself and my family.

This decision was not an easy one. I was leaving behind everything I had ever known, my home, my friends, my family. I felt very unsure about what would happen next. But I knew that I had to do whatever it takes to protect my children.

We hastily packed our bags and made our way to the train station, hoping to catch the last train out of the city. The scene at the station was chaotic - there were crowds of people pushing and shoving, everyone trying to board the same train. Children were crying, their parents trying to calm them down. People were shouting and screaming, desperate to get out of the city before it was too late. As we finally managed to board the train, I couldn't help but feel a sense of relief mixed with uncertainty and guilt. The train journey was long and uncomfortable, but we finally reached the border and crossed into a neighboring country. We were lucky enough to have some friends who took us in and helped us settle down.

As time passed, I realized that I had made the right decision. Several months after we left, our city was hit by a massive missile attack and our house was destroyed. Looking back on that difficult decision to flee the country, I am grateful for the safety and security we found in a new place. It wasn't an easy journey, but it was necessary to protect my kids and start a new life.

A few years ago, I was working as an accountant for a large corporation. At first, I was excited about the job, but after a few months, I started feeling like I was stuck in a rut. I was doing the same tasks every day, and there were no opportunities for me to grow professionally or be promoted within the company.

I tried talking to my supervisor about my concerns, but he didn't seem to take them seriously. He told me that I was doing a great job and that I should just keep doing what I was doing. But that didn't satisfy me. I felt like I was wasting my potential and my career was at a standstill.

I started looking for other job opportunities, but it was a difficult process. The job market in my field was competitive, and most of the available positions required several years of experience that I didn't have. However, I didn't give up. I continued to search and apply for jobs, and eventually, I received an offer from a smaller company.

Even though the new job had a lower salary than my previous position, it offered me the opportunity to take on more responsibility and grow professionally. I knew that it was a risk to leave a stable job for a new opportunity, but I decided to take the chance.

Quitting my old job was a difficult decision, and I was nervous about the future. But looking back, I know it was the right decision. The new company has given me the chance to learn new skills and take on more challenging projects. I feel more fulfilled in my career now and am excited about the opportunities for growth that lie ahead.

Several months ago it was the first time I had been caught in a real dilemma. I had to decide whether to study abroad or locally. Once my parents and I were having dinner, when suddenly they told me it was time to start thinking about my future and... (this is where the nightmare began) that they were ready to pay for my education abroad if it was what I really wanted to do. At first, I was on cloud nine, but then I started agonizing over the decision.

You can't even imagine how painful the process was. I asked my friends what they would do if they were given such an opportunity. Needless to say, opinions differed wildly. Then I made a list of pros and cons and analyzed all 'what-ifs' which threw me into doubt all the time. I also read a few articles about education abroad and found out what other students were saying about their experience. I even tried to consider job prospects in different countries.

I struggled to make a decision because my future was at stake. And, of course, I was afraid to suffer consequences of the wrong choice. It was difficult to imagine what living abroad would be like (taking into account the current situation regarding covid-19). Also, I knew I would have to start my life from the very beginning. And to top it off, I realised I would have to leave my friends and family behind.

After a great deal of thought I decided to seize this opportunity as it's better to regret what you have done than what you haven't. Now I'm planning to study in Canada. Of course, the outcomes cannot be accurately predicted yet, but I hope I made the right decision. We'll see. I'm still worried and fear disappointment but at the same time I'm looking forward to this change.

Many travellers say that it's a truly unique place. The thing is, the country was isolated from the rest of the world for many years. I walked the dog twice a day, fed him, and cleaned up any accidents he had in the flat. But my excitement faded really quickly ‘cause I underestimated what this would take. I mean having a dog is like having a baby. You just can't wake up early to walk the dog one day, and then sleep in the next day. You have to walk the dog twice a day no matter how tired you are, and no matter what you're up to today. Day by day it was getting harder and harder to resist the temptation to do what I wanted to instead of what I promised to. So, my parents ended up taking care of the dog. And it was no longer MY dog, but it was our FAMILY dog. But I think they didn't mind.

Some time ago, I asked my elder sister what music she liked to listen to when she was my age. Soon, I regretted asking this question. Later, you'll understand why.

She played some of her favorite songs, and one of them was 'Wannabe' by the Spice Girls. I kind of liked it and decided to listen to it one more time. On the one hand, almost all the words were clear; however, I wasn't able to sing along. The only line I could sing along to was: "So tell me what you want, what you really, really want." To be honest, even now, I don't remember more than that.

Back then, I took it as a challenge. I found the lyrics and tried to read the first verse quickly. Then I attempted to sing along again. Although I could read the lyrics fast, I ran out of breath while trying to keep up with the vocalist. Every time, I ended up slurring my words like a drunk.

I decided not to give up. I told myself, 'Impossible is nothing.' I played the song over and over until I got tired of it. However, all my attempts to sing along with the first verse failed. Later, I realized I had made a fatal mistake by listening to that song on repeat.

The next day, I woke up with 'Wannabe' stuck in my head. I kept repeating those few lines from the verse over and over in my mind. I tried listening to other songs, but as soon as one song finished, 'Wannabe' would return, stuck on a loop in my head. I thought I was going to go crazy.

I must say, it's one of the most persistent earworms ever. Once it buries itself in your brain, it feels like you'd need surgery to remove it once and for all. Out of curiosity, I decided to google more about this girl group. What I found shocked me a little. This song is actually at the top of the list of the catchiest songs of all time. If only I had known that earlier.

I think that my best friend Ann is a rare example of a person who expresses her feelings freely. We've been friends for many years, and I see her almost every day. So I know what I'm talking about. I mean I have enough evidence to prove that she's an open person. Oh no, to say ‘open' is to say nothing. I think she's too open about her feelings.

For example, she tells people when something is bothering her, when something makes her feel excited, depressed or uncomfortable. She isn't afraid to tell people about painful or embarrassing situations that she experienced. And I know that she always says what she means, but not what other people want to hear. What's more, she posts a lot of personal details on Facebook and Instagram. I always joke that if we stopped being friends, I would still know as much information about her feelings and opinions as I do being her best friend and communicating with her every day.

On the one hand, I admire her ability to open up even to strangers ‘cause this helps her connect a lot more with other people. Her openness encourages other people to open up, and this helps to create a more open and trusting environment. Also, Ann is very easy to deal with, and it doesn't take much time to get to know her. When she is offended, she shows it and says that she's offended and explains why. When she's angry or embarrassed, she doesn't hide her emotions as well. Dealing with her doesn't require guesswork to understand what her opinion about something is, whether she's happy or not and why. You know, I find it really stressful and annoying to deal with people who have a blank and emotionless expression on their faces at all times. I can't read anyone's mind. And I don't want to.

On the other hand, I don't think it's good to be an open book all the time. I always tell her that she should be selective about who she tells about herself. First of all, it can be dangerous for her. And this makes her vulnerable. Also, I think she discloses too much too soon. This turns some people off. I'm sure it would be much better if she kept self-disclosure to conversations with close people. And it seems to me her being too open is the main reason why she's still single. This drives some guys away and makes them lose interest. And I have to say that her openness isn't always appropriate. I'm a total workaholic, so I almost never allow myself to step away from my endless to-do lists and take time for myself, even on weekends. But last Friday, I came home from work, collapsed on the sofa, and passed out. When I woke up on Saturday morning, I realized I needed a full day of doing nothing to reboot my system. I was on the verge of burnout. So, I decided to visit a spa center.

I went alone because I didn’t want to talk to anyone. If I had invited my friends, I would have had to engage in conversations, which would have drained all my energy. So, I kept my plan to myself.

I spent some time in a steam room, then moved to a sauna with dry herbal steam. I swam in a pool and even stepped into a snow room once. Between sauna sessions, I sipped herbal tea.

But what I enjoyed the most was the Japanese bath. There were two hot tubs (one at 45C and the other at 40C) plus a swimming pool with water at 6-8C. First, I sat in the hotter tub for about three minutes, then moved to the second one. After that, I plunged into the cold water before returning to the hot tub. I repeated this cycle several times. By the end, I felt like I was born again.

Some time ago, I told my husband that I was fed up with staying indoors almost all the time, both at work and at home. He promised that we would spend the whole day outside the following weekend. And we did.

My husband suggested going for a bike ride through the countryside. I agreed, even though I hadn’t ridden a bicycle since childhood. So, we rented two bikes, which didn’t cost much, and set off for our country house, which is in a beautiful area near a coniferous forest. Funnily enough, we had only ever had barbecue parties in the garden there and had never really explored the nature around us.

We took some food because we weren’t sure if we would be back quickly or spend the whole day cycling. We also brought a navigator to avoid getting lost in the middle of nowhere. At first, I rode at a snail’s pace, focusing entirely on balancing and steering. Of course, that meant I couldn’t really appreciate the scenery. But it was fun. It felt a bit like being a kid again.

Soon, I got the hang of it and started riding confidently. We passed cows grazing in green fields, ducks hiding in the grass, and beautiful wildflowers with butterflies fluttering around them. We often stopped to take photos and soak in the stunning views. Overall, it wasn’t a strenuous ride. Whenever we felt tired, we simply wheeled our bikes along.

By evening, we returned to our starting point and headed home. We were physically tired, but it helped me recharge my batteries, and it was fun.

A famous person I’m dying to meet is Volodymyr Zelensky. He’s honestly one of the most inspiring people in the world right now. I’ve been following his story for a while, and what really amazes me is how he went from being a comedian to becoming the president of Ukraine… and not just any president, but one who ended up leading his country during a full-scale war.

I first saw him in that show Servant of the People — it’s actually on Netflix, by the way. It was such a clever idea: a regular school teacher suddenly becomes president. At the time, it felt like pure comedy, but now it almost feels like a documentary. The fact that he played that role and then actually became president… it’s just surreal.

These days, he’s everywhere making speeches, visiting soldiers, and working with leaders around the world. But even with all the pressure and global attention, he still comes across as real and grounded. You can tell he’s not just putting on a show. He’s really carrying the weight of what’s happening.

If I ever got the chance to meet him, I’d love it to be somewhere quiet in Kyiv… just a small café, nothing formal. I’d want to ask him how he finds the strength to keep going, how he makes tough decisions, and whether he ever misses his old life, the simpler one.

To me, he’s not just a leader. He's a symbol of courage and resilience. And that’s exactly why I’m dying to meet him.

A famous person I’m dying to meet is Melania Trump. I’ve been fascinated by her for years. The first time I saw her was when Trump started his presidential campaign, and she was just… different. Quiet, elegant, kind of mysterious… not your typical First Lady. It’s insane! She’s literally everywhere. You open a magazine or scroll online and there she is, usually looking flawless. Even people who don’t care about politics know her name. But the strange thing is, no one really knows her. She doesn’t talk much, she keeps her opinions to herself, and I think that just makes her even more interesting.

You know, I’d love to meet her in New York… maybe bump into her at a quiet, upscale café or some kind of fashion event. I imagine she’d be super calm, polite, and observant. I wouldn’t even ask her about politics. I’d ask about her life before the spotlight, how she handled all that pressure, and what it was really like living in the White House with the whole world watching. And honestly, I’d also love to hear about her style like, where she shops, who helps her pick those incredible outfits, and how she always manages to look so put-together without saying a word.

There’s just something powerful about someone who says so little but still makes headlines. That’s what I find really fascinating about her. She’s a mystery I’d love to figure out.

Last summer, my friend suggested going for a bike ride in the countryside. I agreed, even though I hadn’t ridden a bike since I was a kid. One day, we rented two bikes and headed to my friend’s country house. It’s in a really beautiful area near a big forest. And it’s just about an hour’s drive from where I live. The funny thing is, we’d been to the house so many times but only ever had barbecue parties in the garden. We’d never actually explored the nature around it.

We packed some food because we weren’t sure if we’d be back quickly or spend the whole day out. We also brought a navigator, just in case we got lost in the middle of nowhere. At first, I was super slow - I was focused on just balancing and steering, so I didn’t really notice the scenery. But it was still fun and kind of reminded me of being a kid again.

After a while, I got used to it and started riding more confidently. The countryside was amazing. There were cows grazing in the fields, ducks hiding in the grass, and wildflowers everywhere. I stopped a lot to take photos and enjoy the view. The ride wasn’t hard at all. Whenever we got tired, we just walked our bikes and soaked in the peaceful surroundings.

By evening, we went back to the house and then home. We were tired but happy. Honestly, it was such a refreshing experience. It made me feel like a kid again, bringing back those carefree memories from childhood. Plus, it was a great break from my daily routine. I didn’t think about work or any problems the whole time.

Last Sunday, I went to the village to visit my grandparents. During the pandemic, I didn’t visit them at all because I was afraid to infect them. I missed them very much. My grandpa even said he was more afraid to die of loneliness than of coronavirus. So since the pandemic, I’ve been visiting them more often to make up for the time we lost even though it takes me 5 hours to get there.

My grandparents live in a quiet and beautiful place by the river. They have a cozy house with a big garden. There are lots of flowers, and sometimes orchids bloom too. You know, being there is like travelling back in time. Everything reminds me of my carefree childhood: my toys, old CDs, my bicycle. It feels like you step into another world. All the walls are still covered with old wallpaper. My grandmother doesn’t allow us to remove it, and she refuses to get their house refurbished because she wants to keep all their memories alive. She says they both love their 50-year-old chairs and armchairs, their old wooden table in the kitchen, paintings, clay pots, old pictures, and lots of things they bought when they were young.

You know, I think she’s right. There’s something special about this old house. It’s a magical place, and I really love spending time there. When I visit, I enjoy going fishing and exploring the countryside during the day. In the evenings, I watch the sunset from the backyard. I drink hot tea and eat cinnamon buns. My grandmother always bakes them when I come because she knows how much I love them. If I didn't have so much on my plate and if the trip didn't take so long, I would visit them more often.

This shot is truly something to be treasured as, first of all, it reminds of my childhood every time I look at it. Also, this is one of the few photos where the whole family is depicted and all of us look genuinely happy. You know, nowadays people are really busy and don't have time to attend family gatherings. And, unfortunately, this was the last photo of my grandfather taken before his death.

I have to confess that I'm an avid selfie-snapper because when someone else takes a picture of me, I'm almost never satisfied. For this reason, I remember all those 2 or 3 cases when I didn't delete a picture taken by another person.

I think I'll describe one close-up which drew the most likes and comments on Facebook and Instagram recently. It sounds silly to care about something as small as a like on a picture, but it's our reality. To tell the truth, I didn't expect that photo to break the Internet but it did.

I think that my best friend Ann is a rare example of a person who expresses her feelings freely. We've been friends for many years, and I see her almost every day. So I know what I'm talking about. I mean I have enough evidence to prove that she's an open person. Oh no, to say ‘open' is to say nothing. I think she's too open about her feelings.

If something is on her mind, she always lets people know about it whether they want it or not. For example, she tells people when something is bothering her, when something makes her feel excited, depressed or uncomfortable. She isn't afraid to tell people about painful or embarrassing situations that she experienced. And I know that she always says what she means, but not what other people want to hear. What's more, she posts a lot of personal details on Facebook and Instagram. I always joke that if we stopped being friends, I would still know as much information about her feelings and opinions as I do being her best friend and communicating with her every day.

On the one hand, I admire her ability to open up even to strangers ‘cause this helps her connect a lot more with other people. Her openness encourages other people to open up, and this helps to create a more open and trusting environment. Also, Ann is very easy to deal with, and it doesn't take much time to get to know her. When she is offended, she shows it and says that she's offended and explains why. When she's angry or embarrassed, she doesn't hide her emotions as well. Dealing with her doesn't require guesswork to understand what her opinion about something is, whether she's happy or not and why. You know, I find it really stressful and annoying to deal with people who have a blank and emotionless expression on their faces at all times. I can't read anyone's mind. And I don't want to.

On the other hand, I don't think it's good to be an open book all the time. I always tell her that she should be selective about who she tells about herself. First of all, it can be dangerous for her. And this makes her vulnerable. Also, I think she discloses too much too soon. This turns some people off. I'm sure it would be much better if she kept self-disclosure to conversations with close people. And it seems to me her being too open is the main reason why she's still single. This drives some guys away and makes them lose interest. And I have to say that her openness isn't always appropriate. I mean that by expressing what she is feeling, she not only passes some of her emotion to others, but she also has to be ready to deal with the aftermath of that disclosure. But she isn't.

Then one day, we just sat down and said, ‘OK, let’s do this. Let’s pick a gym, choose the days, and go together.’ I think if it had just been me, I probably would’ve signed up, gone once or twice, and then stopped. But knowing that my friend was doing it too made me feel more motivated.

We chose a gym near both our homes, agreed to go every Monday and Thursday after work, and even made a shared playlist to keep us going. At first, it was tough, (I mean, sore muscles, early alarms), but we kept showing up because we didn’t want to let each other down.

What made it interesting was how it slowly became part of our routine. We started feeling better, sleeping better, even eating better without really planning to. We actually looked forward to those gym sessions, because it wasn’t just about working out, it was also about catching up and laughing about how unfit we were at first. So, deciding to go to the gym together made all the difference. It wasn’t just about fitness. It was about support and sticking to something because you’re not doing it alone.

Actually, I planned to buy this device a long time ago, but there was always something that prevented me from doing that.

I understood I needed it in order to check notifications in a more polite way, just at a quick glance and to stay informed without rudely interrupting activities with real people. Now I can't imagine my life without this device. It is just as cool as it sounds. Its greatest feature is receiving notifications. I no longer have to dig my phone out of my bag to determine if the notification is important or I can deal with it later. All I need is just a quick glance at my wrist. So now I can stay informed without interrupting activities with real people, for example, at a business meeting. Plus, I no longer distract viewers in a movie theater with a bright smartphone screen to see who just sent me a text. It's also really helpful when my smartphone isn't easily accessible. Say, I'm cooking or driving… I turn my watch to face me and say: 'Hey Siri, do this or that.' I answer many calls in the car and have perfectly normal conversations even with both hands on the wheel. The microphone works shockingly well. Also, I would often not feel my iPhone vibrate from my pocket, so I had to periodically check my iPhone. With Watch, I never miss the tap on the wrist.

This picture depicted a picturesque rural landscape. In the foreground, there were a few nice small cottages with beautiful gardens, people doing their everyday chores, cows and ducks. The dominating colours in the foreground were bright. At first glance, the scene seemed peaceful, and it showed that humanity tamed nature as it yields the necessities we need to live. I think the artist skillfully managed to capture this contrast.

I don't know what message the artist wanted to deliver, but for me it was like a silent reminder that humanity is small and impotent in front of raging rivers, violent storms, and other natural phenomena. I was more than impressed by this painting. It is a real pity that now I can't recall the name of the artist and that masterpiece.

By far the most beautiful and impressive object is Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France. This is a medieval Gothic building which has become a truly iconic landmark. I'm sure there are no people in the world, except newborn babies, of course, who have never heard of and cannot recognise this cathedral. It is one of the most visited museums not only in France, but in the entire world.

What makes an immediate impression on visitors to Notre Dame is, with doubt, its immense size.

The second striking thing is its beauty. You can't but gasp in amazement when you, first, see its three big portals laden with sculpted saints and sacred scenes. Then your jaw drops when you see two massive Gothic towers which crown the facade. At first glance, they seem identical twins, but they aren't. The north tower is, in fact, bigger than the south one.

At the cathedral's east end, there's the apse with large clerestory windows. It is crowned with an infamous Gothic spire which recently collapsed in the fire. There are also many exterior flying buttresses constructed to support thin walls.

If you look at the cathedral either side, you'll see porches, chapels and other embellishments. Oh, and I forgot to mention its three great rose windows which have retained their thirteenth century glass.

So, Notre Dame is, undoubtedly, an architectural masterpiece, but not just that. Also, it's a Catholic place of worship, and it's a functioning church. People can meet a priest to receive the forgiveness of sins or attend masses and services almost every day.

The person who once persuaded me to do something really important was my father. I’m sure that if it weren’t for him, I would have made a very different choice and maybe even regretted it later. He has always been supportive, but there was one moment when he didn’t just support me. He actually talked me out of quitting something I cared about.

When I was 14, like many teenagers, I did sports and dreamed of becoming a professional athlete. I had trained for a whole year to compete in a national championship. It was a big deal because it only happened once a year. But when the day finally came, I failed to win. I was really disappointed and started thinking I wasn’t good enough. I even made up my mind to quit sports altogether.

After a few missed training sessions, my father noticed something was wrong. He asked me what was going on, and I told him everything. That’s when he had a serious conversation with me. He didn’t just say, 'Don’t worry' or 'You’ll do better next time.' Instead, he gave me examples, like Thomas Edison failing many times before inventing the light bulb. He said, 'If you give up now, you’ll never know what you’re really capable of.'

He persuaded me to give it another shot, to see that one failure didn’t mean the end of the road. He reminded me that the bigger the dream, the more setbacks you might face — and that’s completely normal.

His words really stuck with me. I decided not to quit and trained even harder. The following year, I competed again. And this time, I actually won the championship. That moment became a turning point for me. And now, whenever I feel like giving up, I remember how my dad persuaded me to keep going. And I try again.

The comedy which made me laugh throughout the movie until the very end is Bad Boys For Life. I watched it at the cinema shortly before the coronavirus outbreak. And, by the way, I haven't been to the cinema since that time.

It's a conventional cop movie. The plot is somewhat daft and predictable, but the movie stars Will Smith and Martin Lawrence who are comedy geniuses and therefore they can turn any movie into a belly-laugh comedy. In Bad Boys For Life, Will Smith's Mike and Martin Larence's Markus are still Miami detectives. I'm saying ‘still' as it's the third film in a trilogy. So they're a little older, of course. Marcus has become a grandfather and wants to retire. But Isabel Aretas, widow of cartel kingpin Benito, escapes from a Mexican prison and sends her son Armando to Miami to assassinate the people responsible for his father's arrest and eventual death in prison. Isabel demands that Armando kill Miami detective Mike Lowrey last. So the two detectives re-unite one last time to investigate a string of murders tied to Mike's past.

I laughed for two straight hours. The funny bits are funny. The serious bits are even funnier. I think it's a combination of situation, sharp jokes, and actors' performance that make it absolutely uproarious. Just look at the expressions on Martin Larence's face, and you'll laugh hysterically. Lawrence is a brilliant actor who can tell an entire story on his face in one reaction shot. Also, the movie is packed with funny moments. I'll describe my favourite one. We see Mike and Marcus flying at unbelievable velocity, and pulling off some insane driving stunts as Mike makes his way to their final destination. And even though Mike drives his Porsche recklessly, the car isn't even scratched. But then he parks the car, Martin Lawrence's Markus opens the door and ruins it by whacking it into a hydrant. It's silly, but it evokes explosive laughter. And I think another reason why the movie is truly one of the best comedies ever made is that the jokes are fresh and ‘in the moment'. Many jokes are relatable. I mean everyone can recognise themselves.

In my city by far the most popular place for sports is a 50-meter indoor pool. It's located pretty far from the city centre, which might seem a serious obstacle for people willing to visit it regularly. Nevertheless, it's very popular with city dwellers, and nobody has ever complained about its location as there are a number of things that make this swimming pool easily the best pool in the city.

First of all, it has ample parking space for all the visitors. This means you don't have to come much earlier to find where to park your car. Also, the facility is new and clean. There are spacious locker rooms, so you don't feel cramped and don't have to navigate through wet bodies to collect your belongings. What's surprising is that there are showers with towels, shampoos and conditioners, but the memberships aren't pricy. The pool is really large, so, thank God, even during peak times you don't share a lane with more than 3 people. Several lanes on one side of the pool are used by professional swimmers, several lanes on the other side are occupied by elderly people, pregnant women and beginners. All the other lanes are used by men and women who swim for fitness. You know, all those people who swim fast and overtake each other. I'm really afraid of such swimmers as I have to share a lane with them. Oh, I nearly forgot. There's a gigantic water play space for children where they are looked after by the staff of the pool, while their parents are swimming. I'm sure this is one of the reasons which make people choose this very pool. Also, I can't help mentioning that the water is always warm enough for comfortable swimming, and after swimming you can enjoy spa treatments. One more important thing that appeals to many people (and I'm not an exception) is that it's open from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m., which means that all people have an opportunity to visit it regardless of how early they start their working day or how late they finish it.

By far the most popular place for sports in my residential area is a small gym located within walking distance from my home. I've been visiting it over the last 2 years, so I can easily describe it in detail.

There isn't much equipment, but all the machines are in good condition. You can use weight machines and free weights such as barbells and dumbbells. There are cardio machines such as a treadmill and an elliptical trainer. The gym also allows a small space for stretching. But, in my opinion, it doesn't really matter how big or small a gym is as long as you have enough motivation to go there regularly and do some exercises. I don't understand those people who think that doing crunches on a big blue ball is better than doing them on a floor, or a bench. I think that those who wait until they can afford to buy a pricy membership in a modern gym just try to find an excuse to justify their laziness.

This gym is very popular and is often too crowded as, first of all, it offers memberships that fit any budget and, as I've said before, it's the only gym in the district. It is definitely more popular with men than with women as women usually dislike lifting weights. In general, there are different categories of people there. I see both beginners and seasoned exercisers, even competitive athletes. You can see those who frantically lift weights and see nothing around. Also, there are those people come to the gym religiously every day only to talk, roam around, use the same weight forever, grab on their cell phones, or some other practice that has nothing to do with staying focused on their training.

In any case, this gym is very important for our city (and I like it) as it helps to get more people involved in sport and helps people save their time 'cause they don't need to go to the other end of the city to work out.

I've got a friend who works in the IT industry. He's a software developer. Recently he signed a 1-year contract with the company like Google. And he was offered a relocation package, so he decided to work abroad for at least a year. He asked me to look after his apartment. So from time to time, like once a week or once a fortnight, I go to his place to make sure everything's ok. There is remote control heating, lighting, and sound systems, floor heating and cooling, automatic blinds. Plus, there are 2 or 3 surveillance cameras inside. So I wouldn't have to visit it so often if there weren't houseplants that my friends likes so much. They are like his pets. So they have to be taken good care of.

It's a very spacious 3 bedroom flat in a newly-build block of flats. What I like the most about it is big floor-to-ceiling windows that let a lot of natural light in. There are some elements of a loft style such as massive oak planks, concrete walls, marble panels and some other things made of natural stone glass and steel. There is a surrounding sound system all through the apartment. There are both an eat-in kitchen and a formal dining room, walk-in closets and a bedroom complete with whirlpool tubs and separate showers, a small laundry room, media room and home office.

I like to visit it, but I don't think I would like to live in such a flat. First of all, it's too big to clean without using a cleaning service or having a full-time cleaner. And that's quite expensive, I think. Also, you pay more in utilities to heat and cool those extra rooms, and you spend more on furnishings to fill them up. And, to be honest, I don't see any point in paying ALL the time for a lot of space I will only use SOME of the time. What's more, it doesn't feel like home. And I don't want to live in a flat that is Pinterest-perfect and looks like a museum. In my opinion, a flat shouldn't be as perfect or sterile as a builder's model home. I don't know, maybe I'm saying so just because I envy my friend 'cause I cannot afford to buy an apartment like this.

It's high time that I started a complete renovation of my flat, but it was not until I visited my colleague's apartment several weeks ago that I finally understood what I wanted it to look like.

So, several weeks ago I took my colleague's cell phone charger by accident. As it was on Friday, she asked me to bring it to her place as she didn't want to be out of touch the whole weekend. Thank God, it appeared that she lives in a newly built block of flats in the city centre, therefore it didn't take me much time to get there. She invited me to come in and have a cup of coffee.

My jaw dropped when I entered her flat. It was a very nice studio which looked really stylish and bigger than it actually was. On the one hand, there was nothing special, by the way, very little furniture, but all the elements together created a truly cohesive look. There was a lot of original decor. I thought she'd spent a fortune on it. You can only imagine how surprised I was to find out that she made all this decor herself using twigs, ropes, mason jars and other stuff like that. I also liked floor-to-ceiling windows that let a lot of natural light in and a stunning panoramic view of the city. So by sheer luck I got a chance to visit the flat which I really liked and whose design I'm going to copy.

This happened to me last year. I ordered a book online as a birthday gift for my sister. Her birthday was the next day, so I needed the book to arrive on time. The price on the website was 800 pesos, which seemed fair, so I placed the order using cash on delivery.

But when the delivery guy came, he gave me a receipt for 1,600 pesos, double the amount. I was really surprised and showed him the price on the website, but he said he was just the courier and couldn’t do anything. I immediately tried calling the store’s customer service, but no one picked up. I even sent them a message, but I didn’t get a reply.

At that point, I had to make a choice - either refuse the package and end up without a gift, or pay the full amount and sort things out later. Since I really didn’t want to disappoint my sister, I decided to pay. I knew she would be happy with the book, so that was the most important thing for me at the time.

Right after that, I contacted the online store’s customer service. They said they would investigate the issue and get back to me in 3 to 5 days. I waited, but no one followed up. So I contacted them again, and this time they said it was probably a system error. They promised to refund the extra amount, but it took weeks and a lot of emails to finally get part of my money back.

It was a stressful experience, and now I’m very careful when ordering online. I only use trusted websites and always double-check if the total price is final, especially when using cash on delivery.

Last year, I ordered a book online. It was a novel I had wanted to read for a long time. The website seemed reliable, and the price was fine, so I placed the order.

But when the package arrived, I noticed something strange. The book cover looked different, and the title wasn’t the one I had ordered. In fact, the book I received was a completely different one. It was some business guide instead of a novel.

I contacted the seller and explained the situation. They asked me to return the book and said they would send the correct one. But the return process was complicated. I had to print a form, repackage the book, and go to a post office. It was a lot of effort for a simple mistake on their part.

Eventually, I did get the right book, but it took over three weeks. This experience taught me that even with reliable-looking websites, mistakes can happen, and it’s important to check reviews and return policies before ordering anything online.

Just a couple of months ago I had to buy a new laptop because my old one was freezing every 5 seconds, which drove me mad. You know, at some point, I learnt something really important — you just can’t please everyone. For a long time, I used to try. At work, with friends, even with people I barely knew. Not everyone has to like you. The right people will understand. Honestly, learning that was a bit of a game-changer for me.

At some point, I learned something really important: to live in the present moment. It might sound like a cliché, but it honestly changed a lot for me. I realized that a big part of depression comes from living in the past — thinking about mistakes, regrets, or things you wish you’d done differently. As for anxiety, that usually comes from worrying too much about the future, about things that might not even happen. Psychologists often say that depression is rooted in the past and anxiety in the future. That really stuck with me. I started noticing how often my mind was somewhere else, replaying old conversations or stressing about what might happen next.

Learning to come back to now, through breathing, noticing what’s around me, or just taking a pause, helped me feel calmer and more focused.

Once I understood that, I started focusing more on the present, enjoying little things, not overthinking, and just taking things one day at a time. Honestly, learning that was a bit of a game-changer.

We were frantically searching for clues. Some of them involved solving riddles, putting items in the correct order, or finding a set of objects hidden in the room. At one point, I told him about my complicated situation with my husband. And he shared a different perspective, not just as a therapist, but also as a man. It really made me think. I started seeing things from a completely different angle.

That conversation honestly left a mark. I remember walking away feeling lighter, like something shifted in me. And to this day, whenever I face issues in my relationship, I often go back to that moment and what we talked about. I never expected to have such a meaningful, eye-opening conversation with someone I had never met before, but I’m really glad I did.

Yesterday, I made yet another breakfast for my husband… nothing fancy, really, just the usual eggs, toast, and coffee. But when he sat down and took the first bite, he looked at me like I had just cooked something from a five-star restaurant. He started saying how good it was, how much he appreciated it, and honestly, he couldn’t stop talking about it.

And the funny thing is, he does that every single day. It’s not like I’m trying new recipes or anything; it’s just simple food, but he always makes a big deal out of it. He usually smiles, leans back in his chair, and says something like, ‘Best breakfast ever!’. Even though he says it every morning, it still makes me laugh.

At first, I used to roll my eyes and laugh it off, but after a while, I realized it actually means a lot to me. It’s a small moment, but it makes me feel really appreciated. Like, even the little things I do are noticed and valued. Honestly, it gives me this warm feeling every morning, kind of like I’m starting my day on the right note.

Actually, this happened not that long ago at work. I stayed late one evening to finish up a big project we had coming up… nothing crazy, just a few extra hours to get everything done properly. Honestly, I wasn’t really thinking much about it. I just wanted to make sure everything was ready on time.

The next day during our team meeting, my boss brought it up in front of everyone and said he really appreciated my effort. He even said something like, ‘This is the kind of dedication we like to see’. It kind of caught me off guard because I wasn’t expecting to be singled out like that.

To be honest, I felt a bit awkward. I wasn’t doing it for praise or anything. I just thought it was part of the job. Plus, I know a lot of other people in the team also stay late and work hard, but they don’t always get noticed. So in a way, I felt a bit guilty, like I was getting credit for something that wasn’t just my effort. At the same time, it was nice to hear that what I did didn’t go unnoticed. Still, I wasn’t sure how to react. I just smiled and tried to downplay it. I guess it reminded me that sometimes small things you do can stand out, even if you don’t think much of them at the time.

A few weeks ago I cleaned my room without my mom having to remind me a hundred times. I just picked up my clothes, vacuumed the floor, and finally dealt with the pile of random stuff that had been sitting on my desk forever. I don’t even know why I decided to do it. Maybe I was just bored, or maybe the mess finally started to annoy me.

Anyway, when my mom saw it, she was genuinely surprised. She literally walked past my room, stopped, and backed up like, ‘Wait… you cleaned? On your own?’ And then she smiled and said she was really proud of me for taking the initiative without her having to ask.

To be honest, it felt kind of good. I’m not used to getting praised for small stuff like that, so it caught me a bit off guard. I just shrugged it off at the time, but deep down it made me feel pretty good… like I’d done something grown-up for once.

I mean, it’s not like I’m suddenly super tidy now, but after that, I kinda realized that doing small things without being told isn’t that hard. And honestly, it made the house feel a bit more chill too, because my mom wasn’t chasing me around to clean all the time.

Honestly, I’m usually the type of person who just buys a package tour and lets someone else do all the planning. It’s easy. You don’t have to worry about anything. But last summer, I kind of got obsessed with the idea of doing something different. I really wanted to take a road trip… like a proper one, with multiple stops and no strict schedule.

Of course, I didn’t want to travel alone, so I called up two of my close friends and suggested the idea. We got together one evening… just at my place, nothing fancy… and started brainstorming. We made a plan based on places we all wanted to visit and how much time and money we could afford to spend. It wasn’t anything super detailed… more like a rough itinerary so we’d have some direction but still feel free to change plans along the way.

The idea was to rent a van, pack up all our stuff… tents, sleeping bags, some food and water… and just hit the road. We wanted to keep it low-key and simple, just enjoying the drive, the music, the small towns we’d find along the way. It felt more like an adventure than a regular trip.

To be honest, I was excited and a little nervous at the same time. I’d never done a trip like that before… no fixed hotels, no real structure. But that was the fun of it. In the end, it turned out to be one of the best experiences I’ve ever had. The planning part, even though it was pretty casual, actually made the trip even better because we all got involved and it felt like our trip from the start.

Honestly, I’m not usually the person who plans stuff. I usually just show up. But a few months ago, I decided to organize a picnic with some friends. It wasn’t anything fancy, just an idea to spend some time outdoors and take a break from all the usual weekend routines.

I didn’t want to do it alone, so I texted a couple of close friends and they were totally up for it. We got together one evening… just hung out at my place. And we started putting a plan together. We figured out where to go, what food to bring, and who’d be in charge of what. It was nothing super detailed… more like a quick plan so we wouldn’t forget anything important, like a blanket or drinks.

We decided on a park just outside the city…quiet, not too crowded… And everyone would bring something: snacks, sandwiches, drinks. We also packed a football and a speaker for some music, just to keep it fun.

Honestly, I was really looking forward to it, but also a bit worried about the weather. You know how it always looks perfect on Friday and then it rains on Saturday. But luckily, the weather held up, and the whole day turned out great. It was super chill… just lying on the grass, eating, talking, kicking the ball around. I’m really happy we made this plan. It turned into one of the best weekends I’d had in a while.

I had been dreaming about a smart TV for a while. You know, I imagined using all its features to make watching TV even better. Finally, last year, my dream came true, and I bought it during the Black Friday sale. The TV itself is fantastic, but the remote control that came with it is a different story. It turned out to be so hard to use that it's been almost a year since I bought it, and I'm still trying to figure out how to use all those features that make this TV ‘smart’. I think this remote control was made to make people doubt their IQ ‘cause, you know, it’s like a mini spaceship control panel. It has more buttons than I know what to do with.

Every time I want to watch a show or movie, it turns into a challenge. For example, it has a touchpad that is supposed to make navigation easier, but instead, I find myself accidentally swiping the wrong way and ending up in menus I didn't even know existed. One time, I somehow changed the language settings to French, and I had no clue how to get back to English. I had to google it.

Plus, I have a really hard time using the back button. It’s too sensitive, so it always causes me to accidentally go back when I didn’t mean to.

Then there's the voice control feature. In theory, it sounds amazing. Just say what you want to watch, and it appears on the screen. But for some reason, it hardly ever understands me. I’ll say, ‘Play the latest episode of Love is Blind’ and the TV responds with, ‘Playing a documentary about sea turtles’. It's as if the remote has a mind of its own.

Despite all these challenges, I use the smart TV remote every day. I literally have no choice now. I just keep hoping that one day, I’ll get used to using it, and it will finally feel as smart as it's supposed to be.

The room I love spending time in is my elder brother's room. The thing is, it's way bigger than mine, so they put a TV and a Sony PlayStation in there. I still think it's unfair that our parents did that, but it is what it is. I used to just feel upset with my parents, but then we sat down, talked it through, and decided that I can play on the console when my elder brother isn’t home, as long as I don’t move or take his things. So every time he leaves the house, I can’t wait to go into his room.

I sit in his big, comfortable chair, turn on the PC5, and start playing my favorite games. Sometimes, I stay there for hours, just playing and enjoying the quiet. Also, for some reason, no noise comes out of his room, so I can listen to music loudly. But when I’m in my room, my mom always tells me to turn down the music because it bothers everyone.

So I really love spending time in my brother's room. It's spacious. No one bothers me there, even if I make noise. And there are a lot of cool tech gadgets that I dream about.

If you had asked me about a place where I’d like to stay for some time just a week ago, I probably wouldn’t have had an answer. But recently, I came across a video on YouTube that completely changed my mind. It showed a stunning, modern house with a sleek design, a big backyard with grass, and an in-ground pool. I was blown away when I saw it. It was exactly the kind of place I would love to stay in for a while.

The house in the video was a rectangular, ultra-modern home with clean, straight lines, made of concrete, steel, and glass. The outside was either white or black, but honestly, the color didn’t matter much. What really caught my attention was the overall design - a geometric building without a traditional roof, just a smooth, modern structure.

Inside, the house was just as incredible. It was a two-story home with an open floor plan, high ceilings, and big floor-to-ceiling windows that filled the space with natural light. The style was minimalist, but it had some loft-style elements like concrete walls, oak floors, and marble accents. I loved how modern and simple it looked, yet it still felt warm and comfortable.

Of course, the house was equipped with all the latest technology—remote control heating, lighting, sound systems, automatic blinds, and even floor heating and cooling. One of my favorite features was the surround sound system that played music throughout the house.

It was definitely a large house—tall ceilings, spacious rooms, huge staircases, garages for several cars, and every room you could dream of. There was a kitchen, dining room, walk-in closets, media room, home office, and even bathrooms with whirlpool tubs. It had everything to make staying there feel like a dream. I think a house like this would be perfect in a big city like London or New York, where it would really stand out.

Well, nowadays there's so much noise around that sometimes silence is a luxury I can no longer afford. So time and again I go to some quiet places not to forget what 'silence' is. My favourite one is a coniferous forest which is just a 20-minute drive from the city. This is a magical place where quietness is almost tangible.

I like to walk, enjoying the air, the scents, and the vegetation. I usually move slowly, calmly, and mindfully. The older I become, the more I appreciate each opportunity to take the time to walk or sit and enjoy silence, especially when I feel that I'm on the verge of burnout. When it's warm, I spread down a small carpet and sit under a pine tree, reading a book or just enjoying the nature.

This is by far the best place where I can take a break from a constant stream of noises to reboot my brain and unwind. Also, it is there that I can rid my mind of negative and unnecessary thoughts, slow down, catch a deep breath, set my mind straight, think about my life and focus on what I really want. If I'm feeling blue, a walk in the forest helps me to set myself in the right mood. When I feel stressed and exhausted, it helps me to recharge my batteries.

I usually notice a huge difference in the way I feel before and after I go there, and this is definitely what keeps me coming back for more.

The person I really enjoy spending time with is my boyfriend Denis. You know, it's like every time I say 'Goodbye' to him, right after that I start looking forward to the next meeting. This is what, in my opinion, shows how much I like being around him.

To tell the truth, if it hadn't been for his persistence, I wouldn't have even started communicating with him. So, how did it all begin? We met by accident. We went to the same fitness centre and saw each other from time to time, but I didn't pay attention to him as he wasn't my type. Once we had small talk at the reception and after that he befriended me on Facebook. Gradually we started communicating a lot and have become inseparable friends.

Everybody says we are a perfect match as, on the one hand, we have a lot in common, on the other, we are really different and complement each other, so it is always interesting for us to be together. We both like walking in the park. We can speak on the phone till morning as every hour feels like a minute, and I don't realise how time flies when we are together. We often go to the cinema or just stay at home at watch a good film together. He invites me to different cafes and restaurants where we can taste new dishes and just chat. We discuss our plans for future, visualizing what life will be like when we get married. We like reading books and discussing them. When the weather is bad, we like playing board games such as backgammon or checkers at home.

Actually, it doesn't really matter what we do as long as we are together. What I know for sure is if it weren't for him, I would have missed out on so many things. For instance, I wouldn't have jumped with a parachute or swum in a cold river. Whatever we do, we always have a good time, laugh and enjoy each other.

The person who has always stood by my side is my mom. For this reason, it will come as no surprise if I say that I am more emotionally attached to her than to other members of my family, although I have really close relations with all of them. So we spend quite a lot of time together.

When we meet, we usually spend time in the kitchen, drinking tea and having long conversations on different topics. Aso, I like going shopping with her. When she accompanies me, I choose outfits which then become my favourite ones. Actually, it doesn't really matter what we do as long as we are together. Whatever we do, we always have a good time. Sometimes I joke that if we got lost on a desert island, we wouldn't get bored for at least 50 years.

To tell the truth, there just aren't words to describe what my mom means to me. And it cannot be otherwise as we've shared so many things throughout my life. When I was a child, she dropped everything in her schedule to drive me to different clubs and lessons such as singing and dancing. When I felt bad, she would come to my room and ask if I wanted to talk. If I did, she would sit with me until I felt better. And even now whatever happens to me, she is the first person I rush to. I hide nothing from her and talk to her about everything even things that aren't always easy to talk about. She never judges me, no matter what. She is the most important person in my life.

Recently my friend invited me to grab some coffee and catch up. One of the things he told me was that he started thinking of investing his life savings in cryptocurrency. He said it was the best time to invest 'cause the price of bitcoin and several other leading cryptocurrencies had suffered huge falls in December, so the price of bitcoin plunged to about 70000 dollars, but some analysts are predicting the price of bitcoin could hit 100000 dollars by the end of the next year. And there are a lot of new coins that he thinks will make a good investment as well. One more reason why he said cryptocurrency could make a good investment is that everyone says cryptocurrency is the future 'currency of the internet' and ultimate store of wealth. What's more, transactions are fast, digital, secure and worldwide, which allows the maintenance of records without risk of data being pirated.

Despite all this, it was obvious he couldn't make up his mind. I'm sure what I told him didn't help him at all 'cause my knowledge of cryptocurrency is limited. All I could tell him was a couple of stories of bitcoin millionaires and losses. For instance, I told him a sad story of some guy who accidentally threw away 7500 bitcoins when he got rid of an old laptop hard drive. He bought them when they were worth 1 dollar. And they are worth over 200 million dollars today. He now wants to dig up his local rubbish tip, hoping to find the old drive. Also, I told him that if I were him, I wouldn't invest more than I can afford to lose, and that I wouldn't invest all my life savings. In my opinion, the discussion was really fruitful as it helped me form a balanced opinion on this matter. And now I'm planning to invest a small amount of money in bitcoin in the near future. But it seems to me my friend began to doubt even more.
